item.title: The evolving Harris current sheet model
item.description: In many space physics papers investigating nonadiabatic current sheet scattering, the simplified Harris model is used. In Cartesian coordinates, it takes on the simple form $$\mathbf{B} = B_x\tanh\Big(\frac{z}{L}\Big)\hat{\mathbf{i}} + 0\hat{\mathbf{j}} + B_z\hat{\mathbf{k}}$$ where \(L\) parameterizes the current sheet thickness. This is nice approximation for a relatively static magnetosphere, but it doesn’t capture a thinning current sheet. For that, we’ll need to make the change \(L=L(t)\). In turn, this will induce an electric field. What is the expression for that field? Prerequisites: To understand this post you’ll need to be familiar with Maxwell’s equations. To understand the motivation of this post, familiarity with basic space plasma physics and the structure of the magnetosphere is necessary.
